I've seen my dogs trained by a few different trainers and they were all incredibly terrible people. They would sometimes take on multiple dogs at once and just throw them in a kennel in their garage. They would put chain collars on the dogs that woud choke them if they misbehaved. Both my dogs had vastly different personalities and their responses were as follows:  The regal spoiled brat would obey, but he would tear up and not look at myself or my parents. The sweet heart who loved food cried loudly. It absolutely broke my heart to watch some of the training and also knowing where they were being kept when we weren't there. They were utterly terrified the entire time. They would often piss themselves and get punished harshly for it. Even my parents had a difficult time convincing themselves that this was for the benefit of our dogs. Eventually however, they realized that the only thing they were doing for our dogs was traumatizing the shit out of them. When the decision was made to bring them home and never trust any trainer ever again, the damage was quite evident. They were prone to aggressive fights with each other, even growling violently at us, and had crying episodes as well as a ton of seperation anxiety. If any of us left the house at all, they would walk to the door and cry loudly. Never trust trainers. Ever.

Artstyles still have to make the exaggerated design of a real-world character or object still look like that character or object. For example, great danes have really big paws and big floppy ears, so it'd make sense to put it on a cartoonified great dane. This just looks like they told the designer to fit what they think a great dane looks like in the artstyle of this movie.

Honestly, the general plot the movie was built from could've actually been good if they didn't do anything that they did (with a few tweaks of improvement).  > an unruly dog that lives for destruction - in a logical sense and not causing natural disasters. The family has had enough of the trouble, having lost a lot of money in repairs and almost all of their relatives and friends, and so they hire a well-renowned dog trainer, who IS evil and seeks to train the dog for their own benefits and leave the family in the dust, of whom will never see their dog again. The dog is essentially in prison, with diets, rules, and training that restrict any fun or freedom. The training is actually done properly, with the goal in mind of making a well-mannered and well-groomed pooch. The dog is finally tamed, by way of fear, loneliness, and loss of the things it loves, and it goes on to win many awards. The family finds out on tv, but their efforts to get their dog back are futile. At one particular dog show, at the peak of the dog's career, the family enact this crazy plan to get back their dog, but their dog is stuck in it's tamed ways and refuses to leave the show. After many attempts, Then comes in the youngest family kid, the dog's best friend and the one that actually had fun in all of the chaos, because they're a naive and unresponsible child that the parents believe to have been badly influenced by the dog from a young age. The kid finally breaks the dog out of it's forced state of mind with it's favourite squeaky toy and a some play acting on the kid's part to get the dog riled up. The dog gets all excited, barks, and leaps into the kid's arms to lick their face. The family ends up getting a portion of the dog's earnings in shows and compensation for their troubles while the trainer is found out and sent away for their crimes. The family is now pretty rich and move into a bigger house with a huge yard that they dedicate entirely to their dog, and also a large pool. A happy family that works through their problems.  Boom! There's a story.

If the film is animated then its a very similar to how the videogame industry handles bad games. At a certain point in development everybody working on the project knows they are working on a piece of crap. Too much money has likely been sunk into that project to throw it out. So they just release it anyway and hope to survive the 'controversy', 'hate' or what have you. With how 'free for all' Netflix was and probably still is with handing out money to people with a show idea this can happen with quite frequency.

My conspiracy theory on why movies like this are being made:  There have been many Netflix shows in the past and some current ones that are pretty good and entertaining, however as time passes, those shows start to lose their luster. I think movies like this are being made so that when people watch them and end up hating them they'll look back on the older movies that lost their spark and say "You know what, that one wasn't as bad as whatever the heck this was." Thus Netflix keeps those older but better shows decently popular because bittersweet nostalgia is better than being stuck in your house, bored out of your mind and trying to entertain yourself to no avail with freaking Marmaduke The Living Mustard Gas Bomb.

One of the main problems with the animation of this movie is that it is clearly more suited to 2D than CG. You canâ€™t just animate anything in CG because the fact that it is 3D inherently chips away at the suspension of disbelief and gets closer to the uncanny valley. Characters with super exaggerated proportions just look weird in CG. Itâ€™s like how Fairly Odd Parents characters just didnâ€™t look right when animated in CG for the Jimmy-Timmy Power Hour. I mean just look at how much better the designs of the end credits 2D animations look.

The whole reason that the marmaduke comics are funny is that the jokes are short, simple, and witty. This is the opposite of that. That's why most comedies based on funny comic strips are kind of bad(SOME are good, but far from all). The jokes in those strips are specifically made for a short, 3 or 4 (or in marmadukes case, one) panel presentation, and they're good BECAUSE they deliver a nice laugh with only a few sentences. Thats why they flop when you try to draw them out for a whole movie. It's like trying to make a movie out of a knock knock joke or pun.

The really sad thing is that Marmaduke was a fun, daily single panel (6-panel in color in the Sunday funnies) comic by Brad Anderson.  From what you show of the 'film' (by appearances, closer to the CG version of projectile vomiting), not only did they almost completely ignore the art of the original work, but as your review makes clear, they also completely ignored the well-meaning, loving dog that Marmaduke was in the strips. He didn't talk, much of the humor was in comments by the family members to people that had never encountered Marmaduke, or (sometimes strange) events that would happen around Marmaduke, often that he had basically NO responsibility for (one strip I just saw on a Google search, showed Marmaduke and the dogs of the neighborhood all walking around together, and they ALL decide to stop to sniff the local hydrant...that inexplicably -apparently in general offense at all the sniffing- starts to rumble and spit what looks like steam, scaring the dogs away just before the pipe below it apparently bursts with such force that the hydrant is launched into orbit, and is then spotted by what seems like an astronomer [portrayed by a voice bubble from America on the globe of the Earth, as the hydrant is whizzing around the world] who inaccurately -at first- describes it as a UFO, then corrects himself as he recognizes it for a fire hydrant. No explanation, except that Marmaduke was there when it happened)...  Yes, he was rather destructive, but not through malicious mischief, but incidental events (being so enthusiastic that his wagging tail knocks nearly everything down to the floor)...but was he a character to make a movie about? ...much less a BAD movie about...? No, not really. The humor in Marmaduke's strips was the directly-to-the-punchline type, not the build-up/THEN punchline scene type... These guys just wanted a dog character with name recognition they could give the 'Beethoven' treatment in a trash/throwaway 'animated' film, hoping to make a quick buck with parent nostalgia (from the old strip days), and a sad belief that kids think that anything destructive is hilarious, so they'll obviously LOVE THIS!!  I'm glad it got panned. I just hope they never made their money back from ANY source, and it will be used as an excuse to prevent both the 'animation studio' and the 'production staff' from ever making a movie again.
âœ¨bouncing eggâœ¨

The sad part about this movie, which I _may_ never watch, is that it's just another film studio trying to milk a cartoon/comic strip that was loved by other generations. I've read only a handful of strips before, so I went onto the Go Comics website to read some of the earlier funnies. Being a comic established in the mid-1950s, Marmaduke has a lot of the charm that Lil' Folks (later known as Peanuts) had; classic one-liners along with a charming illustration.  I even read a couple of the newer strips, and it seems the comic still holds up to its legacy, even after its original author passed away seven years ago. However, the movie adaptation is horrendous. Disgusting humor, unbearable character design, and bland story telling. Blue Sky _nailed_ it with _the Peanuts Movie_ in 2015. With Craig and Bryan Schulz, son and grandson of Charles Schulz, in charge of the screenplay, every part of the movie was sculpted with care to ensure that it wasn't a soulless reboot, but a love letter to one of the greatest comic strip writers and illustrators of all time.  Getting back to Marmaduke, it's just a gimmick for mimic and cash. Blue Sky didn't incorporate any of today's modern humor, albeit, a few modern songs that felt surprisingly fitting, into _the Peanuts Movie,_ and stayed true to the humor Charles Schulz himself would've used in any of his other cartoons/strips. But _this?_ Brad Anderson wasn't even a _thought!_ It's just a generic, bad kid's movie with the shell of a wholesome comic that didn't deserve to be decimated by a bunch of rookies who animated this movie just to milk that cash cow. Boo. Stinky. Fart. Bad. This is comparable with Season 25 of Thomas the Tank Engine. Barf.

Shame on Danny for disrespecting this cinematic masterpiece. This is the most beautiful thing I have ever laid my eyes upon. The trainer is used to represent greedy tycoons, he views himself as superior to everyone else. Using them to gain money and power, shown in the scene were they get billed. And the scene of the trainer beating up Marmaduke is used to mock movies such as karate kid. the bulldog didn't win because of corrupt judges and racism. Another thing that made this movie great is that Zeus in the end didn't do much wrong. He is another case of nature vs nurture were he was taught to be how he is. This was never how his life would have ended up if it wasn't because of his darn trainer. This movie is a commentary and it tells a story about a dog dealing with abusive owners, trying to win a competition against malnourished dogs who seem to be living a paradise but aren't really and corruption in the dog show department. This truly is the film of a century. Dare I say better than morbius.

Alright so, I would say I'm fairly good at reading intentions and shit Here's my take on what they were trying to do:  The 3 things the studio thinks kids like: Dogs, potty humour, over-exaggerated fx. On that last note, I have been seeing a lot of movies lately going for a "3D caricature artstyle" approach to body design (that is, over-exaggerated features).  Taking all of this in, this movie is clearly for iPad kids. You know, the ones that watch YouTube kids shit. Similar movies from our childhood (1 big example being Madagascar) have this weird pacing that anyone older than like 7 will notice. Everything happens instantly and there isn't a plot really.  They didn't want to make a good movie, just a movie that will distract kids. We live in dark times where a studio doesn't have to spend extra time thinking up something that can be fun for parents, and only fun for kids so that the parents don't have to watch their kids as they watch the movie.

Netflix isn't the first to fail this way, but they still make bad movies in general. In movie history (not just Netflix), movies based off of newspaper comics have NEVER been successful, with three exceptions: Dick Tracy (1990), Dennis the Menace (1993), and Over the Hedge (2006). Every other adaptation has failed miserably, just like the first Marmaduke (2010), and this Marmaduke, made TWELVE years after the first failure.

The animation and character design  is my main worry when it comes to the Marmaduke movie. (I haven't seen the full movie, but the few clips I've seen says it all for me.) Don't get me wrong, I like it when animations have range when it comes to designing body shapes for their characters, but this movie pretends to do that when really, they only have three body shapes in the entire movie. And yes, unrealistic proportions can look good with certain animations and certain art styles (for example, Tim Burton has some incredibly exaggerated proportions and it worked extremely well with the art style). But when it comes to this movie, they clearly didn't bother trying to make it look good, and it just ended up looking terrible. And that's just the characters themselves - the colour picking is so random and the way the characters move just makes me so uncomfortable. So needless to say, I really hate this lazy animation style (coming from an artist who is considering going into animation) :))

Dogs communicate through their body positions. Verbalizing is more like punctuation: if they bark/whine/etc they are yelling at you and you have to look at them to see what they're yelling.  And you can speak back to them with your own body language and the limited vocabulary you taught them (through use of association with body language). So the movie definitely took some liberties with this concept (if they even knew about it) but also considering that it seems like only the trainer could talk to him, that's what I think is happening.  Also, what kind of stupid ass dog trainer takes a dog to a competition he's clearly not ready for and doesn't even keep him contained (away from food)? Those deaths are on his hands, imo

7:50 maybe it's supposed to be portrayal of the trainer being a literal "dog whisperer" in that he just understands dogs like it was another person, there are a lot of professionals in the dog field who claim to be so in tune with dogs that they know exactly what they think, and I think that's why the trainer is "on his level" as far as communication while everyone else just sees a dog who doesn't understand anything and there's n o point trying to understand him. Which is kinda sad tbh, you don't need to be a "dog whisperer" to pay attention to any animal's needs, you just need to take the time and care with them to learn their needs. The movie would be better if it focused on this point more openly because that's something that should be talked about, but it's something that probably very few of us even noticed.  And as for "is marmaduke speaking English or is he barking" I think it's probably neither, I feel like when this is portrayed in most movies (except for Dr. DoLttle where they clearly show that he is speaking the animal's noises back to them) if it's not explained, we can infer that the person is understanding the dog through being in tune with animals so deeply, or through a superpower like telepathy, hearing the dog's thoughts, not spoken words, or feeling like they know the dog's thoughts through empathy and reading its body language. Adversely the person is only speaking in normal human language, but the dog actually understands them, in fact they understand all the other people who aren't talking to them too, this makes sense because dogs have more concern with understanding what we're saying, than we do, we are their whole world, take them into our homes and we're all they know, they are desperate to understand what we're saying, it's why they learn what "good boy" means and "no" because they want to please their parent(s) who they dote on unconditionally. I'm sure a lot of writers do intend it to be telephatic, or that the person understands barking or the dog is speaking English but only to that person, however if it's not explained, I always just assume the person's speaking normally and dogs already know what we're saying, they're just not as capable of expressing their responses in our language, but in this case the character in question understands the dog through experience and a true empathy (even though in real life I feel like a lot  - not all but a lot - of people who claim to understand dogs are full of it).

One thing the writers didn't get about the Marmaduke comics is that it's charm comes from the humans being confused and amused by their dog's antics. Marmaduke doesn't talk or have inner thought bubbles so it's just an everyday family laughing and joking about their dog's odd behavior. When all is said and done, they love their dog. The problem with how this was written is that Marmaduke is given a terrible personality and the plot revolves around fart jokes and other dumb gags.

Turns out, Netflix acquired this show from Legacy Classics (despite it looking like utter garbage), it actually did quite well for Netlfix (with over 15m viewing hours by its second week).
Short Answer: Yes, they are looking for a profit so they create these cheap movies intentionally.  They have been reinforcing the idea of quantity over quality because most will still watch these awful movies and see them as a variety of things to watch while browsing through their platform. Over the recent years, people have noticed and it looks like they're trying to bring in some award-winning shows and movies meanwhile as they try to stay ahead of their other streaming competitors.

I feel like the new Pinocchio is intentionally bad in a different way that Marmaduke is.  Marmaduke is intentionally bad in the sense that the point of it was 100% just to make money and not a single person cared about making it good, but Pinocchio almost feels like the people working on the adaptation (the movie was originally Russian for those who don't know) were aware of how bad the movie was and just wanted to have fun with it.  It felt more like it could've been a self-aware troll movie whereas Marmaduke just feels like nobody cared.

Little kids don't care and new talent need projects to practice on to get better.  These aren't movies for people who are looking for something to watch.  These are movies for the little kids who aren't really paying attention anyway as Netflix just goes through a random selection.
Short Answer: Yes, they are looking for a profit so they create these cheap movies intentionally.  They have been reinforcing the idea of quantity over quality because most will still watch these awful movies and see them as a variety of things to watch while browsing through their platform. Over the recent years, people have noticed and it looks like they're trying to bring in some award-winning shows and movies meanwhile as they try to stay ahead of their other streaming competitors.

2D is not inherently better than 3D but with a lot of 3d movies, I notice the 2d design--which is typically cool--gets lost in translation or abandoned entirely for uncanny stuff like this. I wonder what the 2d tests (if there were any) and the sketches/pre-production looked like for this movie  EDIT: Ok so the end credits seem to imply there WAS some cool 2d somewhere in the process. I know Kung Fu Panda wasn't the 1st to do it, but I feel like the trend took off after KFP1's interwoven 2d scenes and end credits. But what movies like this miss is that the rest of the animation also should be the same quality. Not blaming animators; in things like this, it's budget, ambition or lack of heart from higher ups that tank production.

To be honest, I don't hate the designs, they just really shouldn't be 3D lol. If this was a "Rhapsody In Blue Fantasia 2000" it could be really charming, maybe. And do not get me wrong, I LOVE weird exaggerated overly impractical surreal designs done in 3D. Igor, 2008, one of my favorite animated movies of all time specifically for the exaggerated art style. The animation in this looks like it wants to be a Dr. Seuss CGI knockoff, but even those movies knew you could only go so far with surrealism. They know that people will watch it either way, either because they're kids and don't know any better, they're loyal to the brand and will uncritically accept anything that's put in front of them, or just out of bile fascination. So why make one good movie that takes a year and $70m to make when you could make 100 bad movies that each cost a fraction of the price and make the same amount of money (if not more) all put together?

The Hog Rider is a fast ground troop with medium hit points, low damage, and the ability to jump over enemy Walls. He is unlocked at level 2 Dark Barracks. The Hog Rider (person) is a bare-chested dark-skinned man holding a hammer. He has a Mohawk, wears a brown leather loincloth, a red belt, and a pair of leather sandals, as well as two large golden wristbands and a gold earring. His ride is a large hog, about half his height. It has a brown leather bridle looped around its tusks, which in turn is held by the Hog Rider. Hog Riders prioritize defensive structures above all other targets, and will bypass all other types of enemy buildings and troops while any defenses remain on the battlefield. This is true even if they are under attack by enemy Clan Castle troops, heroes or Skeleton Trap skeletons. Note that like all troops that prioritize defenses, Hog Riders do not consider the Clan Castle to be a defense regardless of whether or not it contains enemy troops, but do consider the defending Grand Warden and the activated Town Hall weapon (if any) to be defensive buildings.  Once all defenses are destroyed, Hog Riders become like any other troop with no preferred target; they will attack the nearest building to them regardless of type, and will turn and attack enemy units if they become aware of any nearby. Strategy Offensive  He can be used to jump over any level Walls, rendering them ineffective against Hog Riders. Note that while this allows Hog Riders free access to what lies behind the Walls, it does not open up gaps for other troops to move through. If the Hog Riders need the support of other ground troops, you will still need to deploy Wall Breakers, a Jump Spell, or Earthquake Spells in order to assist them. Hog Riders can be used en masse, i.e. a "Hog Rider Rush", without requiring any Wall Breakers to break Walls. However, such a strategy sports weaknesses against defending Clan Castle troops, Heroes, Giant Bombs, and Skeleton Traps, a problem which only becomes more prominent at higher levels. At Town Hall 10 and above, Hog Riders can be combined with Miners in a strategy known as Hog Miner or Hybrid. Both troops are able to bypass Walls innately, but Miners do not have a preferential target, allowing them to cover for Hog Riders by dealing with defending Heroes and Skeleton Traps. The combination also has weaknesses against flying Clan Castle troops, as neither are able to target air. At lower levels, Hog Riders are quite capable of acting as distracting troops like Giants; they have nearly as much health as a similar-level Giant, move twice as fast, and do considerably more damage. They work well with the Healing Spell when you group several of them together. A good tactic for using Healing Spells is to place them strategically on a cluster of defenses (at least about 3 or more) and also deploy them shortly before the Hog Riders arrive in the area, deploy them in front of the Hog Riders. This is so that the Hog Riders get the most value out of the Healing Spell, and destroy the defenses without losing too much HP. Spots where Giant Bombs or Bomb Towers are/may be should be given special attention when deploying Healing Spells. Hogs of the same level as the Giant Bomb will survive a single Giant Bomb, but they're helpless against a pair of Giant Bombs even with a Healing Spell. Heal them after they've gone through a Giant Bomb blast. The Hog Rider is one of the best troop types for drawing out Clan Castle troops, as it can avoid Walls to penetrate deep enough to reach centrally-placed Clan Castles (and enough health to not die before it gets there). Deploy one or a few to trigger the Clan Castle troops, then lure the reinforcement troops to the corner side, and deploy multiple Archers or Wizards to slaughter them, and then deploy the remainder of your Hog Riders. This strategy is especially effective during Clan War raids. However, Skeletons from the Skeleton Trap and Heroes can also easily kill the Hog Riders, as they can only target defenses, so make sure to have some troops that target anything, such as Wizards, which can swipe out the Skeletons. Hog Riders don't target air so flying Clan Castle troops, especially Dragons, can be a big threat. Most mass Hog Rider strategies in Clan Wars require that the Clan Castle troops be killed first by luring. Bring other troops in addition to Hog Riders, such as Wizards, to deal with enemy Clan Castle troops and clean up the base. Poison Spells can be used to kill almost any enemy Clan Castle troop, but beware as the troops will attempt to flee the poison. If the Poison Spells are decently leveled, and you effectively keep the Clan Castle troops from escaping the Poison Spell with distracting troops, they can eliminate almost any troop. They can also be used to dispense of those pesky Skeletons risen from the Skeleton Traps. Time is also a factor to consider. With only 3 minutes in an attack, it is essential to make sure that this whole process and the remainder of the attack is done as quickly as possible to avoid running out of time. Defensive  Defending against Hog Riders is tricky, as their ability to bypass Walls renders them irrelevant. However, the fact that they can jump over Walls and attack defenses means that they may leave behind their ground support (such as Barbarians, etc.), as they will not be able to follow. This will allow your interior defenses to concentrate on the Hog Riders. Another way to defend against Hog Riders is to exploit the fact that they will attack the closest defensive building. You can arrange your base in such a way so that you have high-powered defenses on the inside and lower-powered defense on the outside, with a layer of resources in between. That way, the Hogs will (in theory) complete a loop around your base before being able to attack your interior defenses (Inferno Towers, X-Bows, etc.), by which time they should have all been killed by the interior defenses. You can place Spring Traps and Giant Bombs in between defensive buildings to take out a few Hog Riders at a time; good usage of multiple Spring Traps and Giant Bombs can severely hinder a Hog Rider rush. Hog Riders can be easily killed using "forced pathing". Forced pathing is a strategy that manipulates the Hog Rider AI and makes them go to at least 2 defenses that cannot be prevented by surgical dropping or side clearing. Placing a set of Giant Bombs in between the two can most certainly hinder the attacker progress. They would not be able to heal the Hog Riders in time. Clan Castle troops, Heroes, and Skeleton Traps set to Ground Mode can be an annoyance to mass Hog Rider raids, as Hog Riders will not attack them unless all defenses have been destroyed. Make sure to centralize them if you want to beat Hog Riders. In Clan Wars, Dragons are excellent troops to place in Clan Castles against Hog Riders, especially for Town Halls 8 and 9. They have high HP, meaning they won't die easily and can kill mass quantities of Hog Riders swiftly if not properly lured. Most mass Hog Rider strategies require that the enemy Clan Castle troops be killed first, so if the attacker lures out a Dragon, but fails to kill it, then a 3-star win is next to impossible, much less a 1-star win via destroying 50% of the buildings. Multi-target Inferno Towers can be a severe hindrance to Hog Riders, having high HP to take several hits from Hog Riders, while hitting large groups of them. Although the Hog Rider is certainly not a liability on defense, the fact that all defensive troops are unimpeded by Walls negates the primary advantage of the Hog Rider. Still, for the space they take they are faster and more damaging compared to Giants. Upgrade Differences The Hog Rider undergoes significant visual changes at levels 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Initially, the Hog Rider is a dark-skinned man with a black mohawk and beard. He also has a gold earring in his right ear and sports two heavy golden wristbands, a red belt, and a brown loincloth. The Hog Rider's hammer has two brass bands. At level 3, his hammer increases in size and turns black. The brass bands on the hammer's head disappear, and the hammerhead goes further down onto the stick, creating a button looking object on the top of the hammerhead. At level 5, his mohawk turns from black to orange, making it similar to that of a level 5 Goblin. At level 6, his hammer gains three large, golden spikes and a bronze plating. At level 7, the edges of his hammer start to glow red, and he gains a brown headband but reverts to a black mohawk. At level 8, his hammer is now mostly golden. His hog also gains a headband. At level 9, the gold on his hammer is much thicker. His headband also lightens in color. At level 10, his hammer turns a bright light blue color that resembles the look of ice. This matches the theme of Town Hall 13. It also gains a small same-colored glow. At level 11, his hammer turns a light greenish color. This matches the theme of Town Hall 14. His hog gains gold armour on its face and muzzle.

Such an awful film, and you touched on a lot of the awfulness... but I think it's really worth mentioning the massive and incredibly lazy racism of the portrayals of the opposing dogs. Juan the chihuahua just exists for the sake of an exaggerated  Mexican accent and a few weird references. Zhi's magical combat sequence is probably the most interesting animation in this trash-fire, but it's still just an extremely lazy Asian martial arts trope. Zhi also repeatedly sort of acts as this Asian mystic deus ex machina, swooping in with some hackney vaguely philosophical quote that somehow rectifies the situation. Much like Juan, but far more prominent, that's Zhi's whole thing - just a fluffy pile of stereotypes. Those are the worst, being from still-marginalized ethnicities, but even the remaining dogs like the German Hansel devise their entire characters from incredibly lazy ethnic typing ("Hey, Hansel... better cut back on the strudel!"). The entire third act felt racist in like... a '90s way. Not that it would've been justified then, but even within the realm of lazy racism... it feels dated. Miserable film.

It's pretty simple. Netflix is using their internal data to generate movies that are essentially guaranteed return on investment for them. these are movies they know will get watched by a certain amount of people who are subscribed and will generate a known amount of new subscriptions. as for who is watching, its kids. or more accurately, its parents putting on netflix kids, which has these trash movies. And the production is so bad because netflix has a very specific target they need to hit to make it a "non-risk" investment. Then they can turn around and show investors how they cranked out some dog shit direct to DVD quality crap and made X amount of dollars back. That's also why the casting is bottom of the barrel along with animation and all other aspects of production.   They are making money, not a movie.

This is actually my favorite kind of terrible movie, the kind that brings up countless existential world building questions that it has absolutely no interest in answering. Like, the only thing I can come up with for why the trainer can understand the dog is there must just be people in this world with the inherent ability to speak to animals, and it's just a well known, implied fact about this world. I also can only assume that dogs are the only ones capable of performing various types of magic, since that's what was being shown off for dogs specifically. And like, those two facts together actually make for a very VERY interesting setting that just will never get explored

3D animation can be so cheap and easy to get into now with all of the tools available, and even the garbage has proven time and time again that it can still sell like hotcakes. The same principle applies to live action too, so we aren't going to see any shortage of shovelware (or whatever the equivalent term would be for films) on the market anytime soon. But In the case of real passion projects, almost all of them aren't given enough time or funding from Netflix. I feel bad for all of the creators and animators of such projects that figured getting picked up by Netflix could've been their big ticket.

I don't recall Marmaduke being a bizarro Scooby-Doo. He was a pretty accurate Great Dane lol. We had one when I was a kid and she'd back up on to our laps with her front paws still on the floor because she desperately wanted to be a tiny lap dog. When our parents weren't around, my sister, grandma and I used to hold her leash together while we walked her. She chewed the brick fireplace. When the alarm went off one night and the cops came they asked if we had a dog and we said a Dane. They looked nervous and asked where she was. Turns out, hiding in the basement. When we gave her treats, especially liver, she'd wag her tail so hard if you were too close she'd whip you and leave a mark. That's what Marmaduke was like lol. The jokes were just how insane owning a Great Dane who had somewhat lax training is.

2:28 look at that mouth. MmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmMmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmMmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmMmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm
okay BUT not every recent netflix animation has sucked, imo.  prime three examples: 1. sahara 2. back to the outback 3. the sea beast  i've had quite a bit of free time lately, and i'm not too snobbish to say that all kids movies are just for kids, so i've been going through a couple of the newer netflix kids' selections and calling up my sister to give her reviews so she has new APPROPRIATE stuff to show her kids.   the sea beast is the one that came out most recently, and holy shit - it's way better than any recent disney movies i've seen. it's got some really talented writers and voice actors, the animation is objectively amazing, and it has a heartfelt message that i can really get behind as someone who's worked with animals - every single one of which is a little smarter than most humans give them credit for. solid 10/10 movie. if it helps to convince you, the creators of moana and big hero 6 worked on the movie, and boy, does it show. if pirates, giant sea monsters, evil monarchy, and found family are things you're into, even better.  sahara is the first out of the three that i watched, and i'd give it at least a 7/10. the story isn't super original, very romeo and juliet vibes, and the whole falling in love at first sight trope, but i think they did it decently. the voice acting is a little goofy sometimes, but it's a kids' movie so i don't really take points off for that as the lines and animation are still perfectly synced. animation is, again, top notch, and the movie has some pretty adult jokes that don't cross any lines, so it kept me entertained.  back to the outback, like sahara, focuses on a snake as the main character - and they both shed their skin at the ends of the movies, an interesting parallel that's definitely obvious symbolism but that works really well. this one is heartfelt, has a good message about what it means to be a family and accepting yourself as you are, and i'd highly recommend it at an 8/10. similar animation to sahara, and definitely a few gross scenes but nothing i'd deem inappropriate; one that i both laughed and cringed at is where the main characters (all animals) have to blend in, so they're all being rolled around by some dung beetle allies in, you know, dung. that's not the grossest part, either, but it's still a really sweet movie.   danny, if you happen to see this, PLEASE watch the sea beast, these are all great movies but that one is by far and away the best.

From what I understand about why Netflix is doing low quality content like this may be part of their push for more of the type of content that is "garbage but you can put on in the background to fill the noise", it doesn't make sense why they would go with this approach with something that is animated as compared to something live action, or why they would compete with one of the less interesting aspects of cable television, but that is just my speculation of why they are putting out movies with less budget besides noteworthy cast (even if it is just Pete Davidson in a movie, it was enough to be brought up in videos complaining about it). Netflix is definitely pushing out literally anything to try and save the company as it is currently drowning amidst the streaming wars, but making low quality pieces of media to be forgotten immediately after inception is a weird approach considering that some of their originals are some of the most well produced and highly regarded pieces of media in recent memory.

tbh, at this stage I feel like we are all in the vocal minority at this point. Like honestly, in the grand scheme of things, despite how right we are.....everyone else with different opinions outnumber us. Like when you think about how many families are out there in the US; how many parents out there really think so little of the animation medium or how many people out there don't care about the integrity of live action stuff (my dad being one of them). The type of parents that want to have their kids be quiet and know so little about good media, so they just flip on random cartoons for them to watch so they have some free time.....yeah....honestly I think that those type of people are the ones mainly supporting these videos with views. It's because Netflix is buying from the European and South American animation studios for super cheap. Ah, the age of low budget movies is back. The reason studios are doing this are, sadly, because studios are hoping to appeal to meme culture and the clout chasing generation. Look at how much attention Morbius and the new Minions movie got because of memes; movie reviews on youtube that poke fun at bad movies also bring attention to movies, which means more people go to watch them. Add on top of that, Netflix loves to overinflate their watch numbers by counting a movie as "watched" by watching the first 5 minutes (I think it's 5), so, there's that too...

Cinematic History Fact! They did this exact same thing in the mid 1900's Where major studios would throw out low budget movies, "B Movies " at an incredible rate in order to gain a steady stream of income. I'm talking about Studios vomiting out around 50-ish movies a year, (which roughly amounted to 7,500 movies in the span of 15 years during Hollywood's golden age). In terms of storyline, they were almost reduced to a formula; in essence, all of these movies are basically the same, which allowed them to be thrown out. ("Mr Smith Goes to Washington" Is a prime example of the whole 'hero's journey' plot structure that's still used today)            [Edit: Legit feel bad for the Animator homies that have to work on stuff like this, I would rather do anything else than rig or animate "Pixar mom-ass" for any amount of time]

It's because a bad movie can be more profitable than a sucessful movie. In some states in the US you can list a failed business endeavor as a tax write off, with the amount of money you expected to make being how much is deducted. So if you make a $1mil budget movie, it only makes $500k, and you expected it to make $10mil, you deduct $9.5mil. Do this across several bad movies and you eventually get out of taxes all together.
